abstract: The presence of fault scarps is a first-order criterion for identifying active faults. Yet the preservation of these features depends on the recurrence interval between surface rupturing events, combined with the rates of erosional and depositional processes that act on the landscape. Within arid continental interiors single earthquake scarps can be preserved for thousands of years, and yet the interval between surface ruptures on faults in these regions may be much longer, such that the lack of evidence for surface faulting in the morphology may not preclude activity on those faults. In this study we investigate the 50 km-long ‘Toraigyr’ thrust fault in the northern Tien Shan. From palaeoseismological trenching we show that two surface rupturing earthquakes occurred in the last 39.9±2.7 ka BP, but only the most recent event (3.15–3.6 ka BP) has a clear morphological expression. We conclude that a landscape reset took place in between the two events, likely as a consequence of the climatic change at the end of the last glacial maximum. These findings illustrate that in the Tien Shan evidence for the most recent active faulting can be easily obliterated by climatic processes due to the long earthquake recurrence intervals. Our results illustrate the problems related to the assessment of active tectonic deformation and seismic hazard assessments in continental interior settings.

author_highlights.sentence: We found two surface rupturing palaeo-earthquakes in the northern Tien Shan.
Only the most recent event has a morphological expression in the landscape.
We conclude that a landscape reset has taken place between 7.3 ka and 40 ka BP.
Evidence for active faulting can be easily obliterated by climatic processes.
Due to long earthquake recurrence intervals, active faults might be overlooked.

body_text.title: Trench stratigraphy and structure

body_text.sentence: We developed a retro-deformation of the trench log to reconstruct the earthquake history (Fig. 7).
body_text.title: Trench stratigraphy and structure

body_text.sentence: We show the consequences of the interplay between tectonic uplift and erosion events on the preservation of earthquake surface ruptures, and the implication of these findings for neotectonic studies and seismic hazard assessments in Central Asia.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: We address these issues through a study of the Toraigyr Fault, sited within the semi-arid Ili Basin, in the NE Tien Shan of Kazakhstan (Fig. 1).
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: White lines in Fig. 2B mark additional profiles recorded with DGPS.
body_text.title: Scarp mapping and profiling

body_text.sentence: To the SE of the Toraigyr Fault the south margin of the Ili Basin exhibits a prominent range front, but no fault scarps clearly offset the alluvial fans there (Fig. 1B).
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: However, since no significant topography is associated with this section, the role of the fault here is unclear and we do not consider it in our further analysis.
body_text.title: Geological and tectonic setting

body_text.sentence: Units 3–5 are offset by the fault, tilted and partly warped.
body_text.title: Trench stratigraphy and structure

body_text.sentence: Fault 1 dips 25° to the south at the base of the trench, and becomes gradually shallower one metre above the trench floor (10° to the south), and then runs approx.

body_text.sentence: Unfortunately we were only able to process the photographs from the western part of the survey due to camera focus malfunction, and so our trench site was not covered.
body_text.title: Scarp mapping and profiling

body_text.sentence: DGPS data from the vicinity of the trench show that the scarp height is around 1.3 m (Figs. 5, 6).
body_text.title: Palaeoseismic trench

body_text.sentence: The resulting DEM is shown in Fig. 2B. Fifteen topographic profile lines extracted from the DEM are also indicated (red lines), with two of them shown in Fig. 3.
body_text.title: Scarp mapping and profiling

body_text.sentence: This fault scarp, which we show to result from a single surface-rupturing earthquake, is the focus of our study.
body_text.title: Geological and tectonic setting

body_text.sentence: This is a minimum displacement, because the offset wedge of unit 6a could in fact have come from a similar unit stratigraphically below, as is further indicated by IRSL ages determined for the two units 6 and 6a (see later).
body_text.title: Trench stratigraphy and structure

body_text.sentence: The surface effects of repeated large earthquakes sum to create cumulative fault scarps and/or folding in late Quaternary cover.
body_text.title: Introduction

body_text.sentence: The unit is less consolidated than units 3 and 4 and has a rather chaotic texture.
body_text.title: Trench stratigraphy and structure

body_text.sentence: Two faults were encountered in the trench, both of which offset marker horizons (Fig. 6).
body_text.title: Trench stratigraphy and structure

body_text.sentence: The gravel horizon (unit 4a) probably represents a time of active channel migration – fine silt was deposited on the channel banks and levees, the coarse gravel was deposited where transport energy was high.
body_text.title: Trench stratigraphy and structure

body_text.sentence: Our study area is sited at the western margin of the Ili Basin, which is a ∼400 km long and ∼120 km wide E-W elongated basin bordered by the Tien Shan in the South and the Dzhungarian Alatau in the North (Fig. 1A).
body_text.title: Geological and tectonic setting

body_text.sentence: Offsets were determined along profiles perpendicular to the scarp for and extending for ∼50–100 m into both the hanging-wall and footwall.
body_text.title: Scarp mapping and profiling

body_text.sentence: A trench log was documented noting lithology, grain size, colour, bedding and deformation.
body_text.title: Palaeoseismic trench

body_text.sentence: After the erosional event, a period of alluvial fan deposition led to the emplacement of units 5–4 (Fig. 7D), and the formation of a palaeosol (unit 3).
body_text.title: Trench stratigraphy and structure

body_text.sentence: GPS data show shortening of about 12 mm/a in the eastern Tien Shan (Abdrakhmatov et al., 1996; Zubovich et al., 2010), which increases to ∼20 mm/yr in the western part due to the rotation of the Tarim Basin.
body_text.title: Geological and tectonic setting

body_text.sentence: Many faults here have very extraordinarily long recurrence intervals, as in general strain rates are moderate and the faults tend to break in great, but rare earthquakes (Campbell et al., 2013, 2015).
body_text.title: Discussion

body_text.sentence: These characteristic landforms are a primary target of neotectonic studies because they allow identification of the faults, they can be used to determine long-term slip-rates and, when combined with palaeoseismic trenching, allow the timing and magnitudes of past earthquakes to be uncovered (e.g. Wallace, 1977; Thompson et al., 2002).
body_text.title: Introduction

metadata.title: Assessing the activity of faults in continental interiors: Palaeoseismic insights from SE Kazakhstan
